comment.author: 38197978@N02
comment._content: An entire family of left-side parts. At the same time, a quietly vivid display of character variation, and an overall glimpse of a sweet family.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38197978@N02] How weird, Richard! Now you have started a new fascination for me - which side hair is parted... Should I tag? Joking aside (so long since had parting) would this mean the main hair brusher/arranger (mother?) was left- or right-handed?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38197978@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland]  Or hair sworls?  Perhaps left side parts were common in Kilkenny.  And your thought about the mother as the primordial parter-of-hair is spot on.  I didn't think of that!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38197978@N02] Now eyeing up colleague's hair dos! They're starting to edge away from me... And I'm adding "parting" - think that's more usual this side of Atlantic - though am prepared to sit corrected.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 80456351@N00
comment._content: Hair-parting is a big deal. I recall some judgemental lady telling me sternly that I had to part my hair on the other side, because mine was parted on the "boy's side".

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/la_belle_province] And which side is allegedly the "boy's side"?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/kensaviation] Don't know, Ken. Have heard the phrase, but unsure what it means... Is it something vaguely legal to do with legitimacy?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 55597723@N02
comment._content: Nice photo & expressions. Such a beautiful Family in those days - - -

comment.author: 97609500@N00
comment._content: I had always understood it to be a term used in heraldry, with sinister having to do with the left side of the shield...like a "left-handed compliment".  I've also run into the reference to legitimacy...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66105333@N06] You were not joking when you said Matthew had an impressive signature! Here's a link to the Young' s form for anyone who'd like to see it: www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai003509744/
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Waterloo House was on the northern corner of the junction of Ballytruckle Road and Poleberry in Waterford city. House is sadly now gone.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] Oh that's brilliant! (Not about its demolition, but about a definite location). Thank you again - you are on an absolute roll.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
